title: 105_hr4240
content: The Act may be cited as the "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" and addresses liability for computer date failure. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" addresses liability for computer date failure in cases where only consequential business loss and repair costs can be recovered if certain conditions are met, such as no personal injury resulting from the failure and the defendant providing notice to all buyers. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" requires the defendant to provide notice to buyers and offer free repairs or replacements for computer programs or hardware involved in a date failure after December 31, 1994. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" mandates the defendant to notify buyers about computer systems or software that may experience date failures and provide repair or replacement options. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" requires notification to buyers about potential date failures in computer systems or software, offering repair or replacement options. This subsection does not restrict liability agreements between contracting parties. The term "person" refers to those involved in commerce designing, developing, or manufacturing computer systems, programs, or components. An action against a person not covered under subsection (a) for a computer date failure can be brought in Federal or State court. An action in Federal or State court for a computer date failure against a person not covered under subsection (a) is deemed contract-based, allowing recovery for consequential business loss and repair costs if certain conditions are met, including no personal injury and reasonable efforts by the defendant to prevent the failure. The company must test its systems by simulating the transition to the year 2000 and notify customers of efforts to prevent computer date failure by August 1, 1999. The company must test its systems by simulating the transition to the year 2000 and notify customers of efforts to prevent computer date failure by August 1, 1999. The President's Council on the Year 2000 Conversion will make the notice available on its website. The subsection does not limit contracting parties' ability to enter agreements on liability and damages from computer date failure. Definitions include "action" for damages recovery and "computer date failure" as present or future computer inability. The term "computer date failure" refers to the inability of a computer system or program to accurately process data between the years 1999 and 2000 and beyond, or the potential for such issues to arise. "Computer program or software" is defined as a set of instructions used in a computer, while "computer system" refers to the overall system. A computer system is any electronic device or collection of devices that contains computer programs or electronic instructions and performs functions such as logic, arithmetic, data processing, storage, communication, or control. SEC. 3. TEMPORARY ANTITRUST EXEMPTION. Antitrust laws do not apply to conduct aimed at addressing computer date failure until December 31, 2001, except in cases of boycotting. The definition of antitrust laws includes specific acts outlined in the Clayton Act. The definition of antitrust laws under the Clayton Act includes section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act and any similar State laws.
